trial_identification.studytitle: Enhanced care and support in early labour (ecsel) trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Enhanced care and support in early labour (ecsel): a randomised controlled trial to reduce caesarean sections for first-time mothers.

interventions.interventions: Standard care in early labour is to telephone the midwife in the hospital birthsuite and seek advice on whether or not to come to hospital. The intervention here is that a known midwife will provide enhanced support (via telephone and/or home visiting) to assist women in the early or latent phases of labour to remain at home until labour is well established unless there is a reason to be admitted earlier. The support will include listening to the woman, taking a detailed history, assessing her current stage of labour and coping ability, advising whether or not to come to hospital, suggesting pain relief strategies and providing reassurance. This will be the midwife's main role, whereas midwives usually providing such guidance are concurrently providing care to women already admitted to hospital in labour. The study midwife will also visit the woman at home if this would be helpful (to be decided on an individual basis by the woman and the midwife). The duration of this additional support will vary according to individual needs between around 15 minutes and 3 hours.
interventions.comparator: Women telephone midwives working in birthsuite/emergency department when they want advice re admission to hospital for the birth (standard care).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Caesarean section for any indication (collected by data abstraction from the medical record)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Instrumental vaginal birth (collected by data abstraction from the medical record)
Length of time from hospital admission to birth (collected by data abstraction from the medical record)
Admission to hospital with cervical dilatation <5cm (collected by data abstraction from the medical record)
Use of oxytocin infusion to induce or augment labour (collected by data abstraction from the medical record)
Cost of maternity care (collected via postal questionnaire at 6 weeks after the birth and data abstraction from the medical record)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: From first possible sign of labour until disharge from hospital following the birth.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Use of epidural analgesia for relief of pain in labour (excluding that used solely as anaesthesia to facilitate operative birth) (collected by data abstraction from the medical record)
Postpartum haemorrhage (collected by data abstraction from the medical record)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: In the 24 hours following the index birth.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Apgar score <7. This is a measure of the condition of the newborn baby at, and soon after, birth (collected by data abstraction from the medical record)
Maternal satisfaction with intrapartum care (collected via postal questionnaire at 6 weeks after the birth)
Birth before arrival at hospital (collected by data abstraction from the medical record)
Breastfeeding (collected via postal questionnaire at 6 weeks after the birth)
Neonatal admission to special care or neonatal intensive care (collected by data abstraction from the medical record)
Maternal admission to high-dependency care (collected by data abstraction from the medical record)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Within 24 hours of the index birth

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Neonatal resuscitation more intensive than oxygen and/or suction (collected by data abstraction from the medical record)
Score >12 on Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (collected via postal questionnaire at 6 weeks after the birth)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Women at normal risk of complication having their first baby booked at a participating hospital; live within 30 minutes drive of the hospital; English speaking.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Complications of pregnancy that would indicate early admission to hospital in labour e.g. fetal growth restriction, antepartum haemorrhage, planned caesarean section

trial_design.concealment: Women will be approached at 36 weeks' gestation and informed about the study. Written informed consent will be obtained if they choose to take part. Background data will be collected, then the recruiter will contact a randomisation service to ontain the treatment allocation.
trial_design.sequence: Stratified by site; variable block sizes; 1:1 allocation to intervention:control

fundingsource.fundingname: applied for NHMRC Project grant funding

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study aims to examine whether extra support from a midwife in early labour, before arrival at hospital, can safely reduce the number of women who give birth by caesarean. Women who agree to take part are allocated by chance to receiving this extra care, or to the usual support provided at the hospital. Once they arrive at hospital, care is provided according to the usual hospital practices.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Human Ethics Committee, La Trobe University
